name: Maristan
theoryOfChange: Reviving the Islamic legacy of Maristans by integrating Islamic principles (Ilm al-Nafs) with evidence-based mental health practices to provide culturally congruent care and education.

evaluationSources: Stanford Muslim Mental Health & Islamic Psychology Lab (Research Partner)

ui_signals_v1.recommendation_rationale: Limited match due to weaker results and/or higher uncertainty; review methodology details before deciding.

components.evidence: Accepts zakat (+2); Muslim-focused organization (+2); Asnaf: masakin (+5); Humanitarian service (+2)
components.improvement_suggestion: Clarify zakat allocation policy and eligible use categories for donors.

components.improvement_suggestion: Expand services to underserved populations or geographies with limited nonprofit coverage.

components.improvement_suggestion: Publish beneficiary counts consistently so cost-effectiveness can be assessed.

score_details.score_summary: Maristan shows good alignment and moderate impact, with zakat compliance (minor risk deductions applied).

all_citations.claim: Maristan reports 13.3 months of working capital and a fundraising efficiency of $0.11 per $1 raised.
The organization's total revenue for the 2023 fiscal year was $618,632.
Maristan operates the Maristan Clinic and provides community mental health education and training.
Maristan is identified as a Zakat-eligible organization.

baseline_narrative.amal_score_rationale: Maristan earns a moderate score reflecting its specialized mission in global health and efficient fundraising, though its overall rating is constrained by low data confidence and limited impact evidence.
areas_for_improvement: Limited data confidence due to a lack of third-party verification and external ratings
Need for more transparent reporting on specific program expense ratios

dimension_explanations.alignment: Maristan aligns with global health priorities by addressing mental health needs and is recognized as Zakat-eligible [4]. The alignment score is medium, reflecting a balanced fit for donors interested in culturally specific healthcare despite a limited historical track record [1][3].
dimension_explanations.impact: The organization focuses on capacity building through its clinical services and training programs [3]. While it maintains a healthy 13.3 months of working capital, the lack of a reported program expense ratio and specific cost-per-beneficiary data results in a medium impact score [1][2].

baseline_narrative.headline: Maristan provides community-based mental health services and clinical training through a culturally informed framework.
strengths: Strong short-term liquidity with 13.3 months of working capital available
High fundraising efficiency with only $0.11 spent to raise every $1
Designated as Zakat-eligible for donors seeking to fulfill religious obligations
baseline_narrative.summary: Maristan is a non-profit organization dedicated to community mental health, operating the Maristan Clinic and various education and training initiatives [1][3]. In the 2023 fiscal year, the organization reported a total revenue of $618,632 [2].

all_citations.claim: Maristan Clinic and provides clinical training

all_citations.quote: Psychological Flexibility: Improvement in 6 core processes

rich_narrative.amal_score_rationale: Maristan earns a moderate score reflecting its specialized mission in global health and efficient fundraising, though its overall rating is constrained by low data confidence and limited impact evidence.

areas_for_improvement.context: The organization currently has an <cite id="1">unknown program expense ratio</cite>, making it difficult for donors to assess the exact percentage of funds reaching direct services.
With a <cite id="2">board size of only 1 member</cite> reported in recent filings, the organization lacks the traditional oversight of a larger independent board.

bbb_assessment.summary: This organization has not yet been reviewed by the BBB Wise Giving Alliance.

case_against.mitigation_notes: The organization is in a rapid growth phase and may be in the process of formalizing its governance and reporting as it scales.
risk_factors: <cite id="1">Program expense ratio is currently unknown</cite>
case_against.summary: The primary concerns involve <cite id="1">incomplete expense breakdown data</cite> and a very small governance board.

confidence.notes: Data confidence is low due to the early stage of the organization and incomplete financial breakdowns.

alignment.explanation: Alignment is strong for Muslim donors due to <cite id="4">verified Zakat eligibility</cite> and a focus on the <cite id="1">urgent cause area of Global Health</cite>.
alignment.improvement: Clarifying the <cite id="4">Zakat allocation policy</cite> and expanding services to more underserved geographies would further improve alignment.

credibility.explanation: Credibility is currently limited by <cite id="1">low data confidence (0.3)</cite> and a lack of third-party transparency seals. While <cite id="2">Form 990 filings</cite> are available, the governance structure is still emerging.
credibility.improvement: To strengthen credibility, Maristan should <cite id="2">expand its board of directors</cite> and publish audited financial statements to provide greater transparency.

impact.explanation: Impact is driven by <cite id="3">capacity-building models</cite> and verified outcomes in <cite id="8">psychological flexibility and self-harm reduction</cite>. However, <cite id="1">insufficient data exists to calculate cost-per-beneficiary</cite>.
impact.improvement: The organization should <cite id="1">publish consistent beneficiary counts</cite> and document a clear theory of change with explicit causal pathways.

donor_fit_matrix.evidence_rigor: Grade C - Verified outcomes but limited cost-effectiveness data

grantmaking_profile.grant_strategy: Direct service delivery and clinical training.

rich_narrative.headline: Maristan provides community-based mental health services and clinical training through a culturally informed framework.

ideal_donor_profile.best_for_summary: Best for donors who want to support the professionalization of Muslim mental health services through a Zakat-eligible, high-growth clinical model.
donor_motivations: Want to address the mental health crisis in the Muslim community
Value culturally and religiously informed clinical training
Seek to fulfill Zakat through healthcare initiatives
giving_considerations: The organization is still maturing its governance and financial reporting
High liquidity suggests your donation supports long-term sustainability
Impact is focused on capacity building rather than just direct aid
ideal_donor_profile.not_ideal_for: Donors who require long-established institutions with large independent boards and decades of audited financial history.

impact_evidence.evidence_grade_explanation: Grade C reflects verified outcomes in clinical samples but a lack of rigorous independent evaluations like RCTs.
impact_evidence.theory_of_change_summary: Maristan creates impact by training clinicians in culturally informed care and providing direct mental health services to reduce disparities.
impact_evidence.why_evidence_matters: Evidence ensures that mental health interventions are culturally appropriate and clinically effective for the target population.

long_term_outlook.room_for_funding_explanation: As a small but rapidly growing organization, Maristan has significant room to absorb capital to expand its clinic and training reach.

peer_comparison.differentiator: Distinguished by its <cite id="3">clinical training focus</cite> and extremely high <cite id="5">revenue growth rate of 376.0%</cite>.

strengths.detail: The organization maintains <cite id="6">13.3 months of working capital</cite>, ensuring significant stability for its clinical and training programs.
Maristan demonstrates lean development operations, requiring only <cite id="1">$0.11 in expenses for every $1 raised</cite>.
The charity has seen an explosive <cite id="5">3-year revenue CAGR of 376.0%</cite>, indicating strong donor trust and scaling capacity.

strengths_deep_dive: Maristan's strength lies in its specialized niche at the intersection of faith and mental health. By offering <cite id="3">Suicide Response Certification Training</cite> and <cite id="7">trauma-informed stabilization treatments</cite>, the organization addresses critical gaps in global health for Muslim populations. Its financial health is bolstered by a diverse revenue stream, including <cite id="2">$147,687 in program service revenue</cite>, which suggests a sustainable model beyond pure philanthropy. Furthermore, its <cite id="4">Zakat-eligible status</cite> allows it to tap into specific religious giving streams to support its clinical mission.
rich_narrative.summary: Maristan is a community-based mental health organization that addresses the psychological needs of Muslim communities through a <cite id="1">culturally informed framework</cite>. The organization operates the <cite id="3">Maristan Clinic and provides clinical training</cite>, research, and healing circles to bridge the gap between traditional Islamic healing and modern psychology. In the 2023 fiscal year, Maristan reported <cite id="2">total revenue of $618,632</cite>, representing a significant <cite id="5">3-year revenue CAGR of 376.0%</cite>. Despite its rapid growth, the organization maintains high efficiency in its development efforts, spending only <cite id="1">$0.11 to raise every $1</cite> in donations. Maristan's programs include <cite id="3">Suicide Response Certification Training</cite> and specialized education initiatives designed to build capacity within the community. While the organization is in an early institutional stage, it has already established <cite id="6">13.3 months of working capital</cite>, providing a strong liquidity cushion for its expanding operations. The charity is <cite id="4">designated as Zakat-eligible</cite>, specifically serving the masakin (needy) through its mental health services, making it a unique option for donors looking to fulfill religious obligations through healthcare-focused giving.
